db8821fe-1280-4a62-ad5f-df9cb3a80f60.title: Dynamic Programming
db8821fe-1280-4a62-ad5f-df9cb3a80f60.chunk:
So, we will now turn our attention to 
a technique called dynamic programming.   So, let us go back to the kind of recursive 
functions that we have been writing.   So, typically recursive functions arise from 
inductive definitions. So, for instance,   we

ef3584a9-0a9c-4036-bf91-ebae2ad6b340.title: Dynamic Programming
ef3584a9-0a9c-4036-bf91-ebae2ad6b340.chunk:
can define factorial inductively. By 
defining the base case the factorial of 0 is 1.   And for arbitrary n bigger than 1, the factorial 
of n can be got by multiplying the recursive   call factorial n minus 1, so inductively, we know 
how to compute that

845d0e32-2a55-4b20-ada7-4f2e6be3073a.title: Dynamic Programming
845d0e32-2a55-4b20-ada7-4f2e6be3073a.chunk:
, and multiplying it by n.
  We can also do this for structures, so we can do 
induction on the structure of a list. So, we can   say that if we want to do for example, insertion 
sort, then for the empty list, it is already   sorted. So, the insertion sor

1a47b382-6f83-473d-9dae-d62672e8e890.title: Dynamic Programming
1a47b382-6f83-473d-9dae-d62672e8e890.chunk:
t of the empty list, 
so this is like the 0 case is just the empty list.   And if we need to sort a list from with X0 to Xn 
with n plus 1 elements, then what we can do is   we can sort the first n elements inductively. 
So, we do insertion sort on X0 to X

744bfcd6-71cc-4ea1-9f1c-eec378eae0a5.title: Dynamic Programming
744bfcd6-71cc-4ea1-9f1c-eec378eae0a5.chunk:
n minus 1,   and then we insert the last element into this.
So, insert is a separate function which is like,   so it is like multiply, so it is a 
separate function that we use to combine   the inductive case with the element which we are 
currently dealin

9823061a-0c62-4afc-8a67-6b3a4c4879e6.title: Dynamic Programming
9823061a-0c62-4afc-8a67-6b3a4c4879e6.chunk:
g with. You can also write insert   inductively, but we will not bother about that for 
now. So, once we have these inductive definitions,   then when we write code for this, then they 
naturally become recursive functions. 
  So, the factorial function wi

e92eb216-318e-4a70-ab1b-38a6f65d1a8e.title: Dynamic Programming
e92eb216-318e-4a70-ab1b-38a6f65d1a8e.chunk:
ll 
say, if n is smaller than 0 or less,   return 1, otherwise return n times factorial 
of n minus 1. Similarly, the insertion sort   function will say that if the list you are given 
is empty, then return that list. Otherwise, insert   into the list up t

23762397-40a8-4c66-8984-ef39da1a4ebf.title: Dynamic Programming
23762397-40a8-4c66-8984-ef39da1a4ebf.chunk:
o but not including the last 
element, insert the last element. And then,   so you assume that this is sorted inductively 
or recursively and then you insert.   So, this is how it works when we have inductive 
definitions, we get recursive programs.   So,

ab324186-61ac-46d7-9852-6ca2b6b4b717.title: Dynamic Programming
ab324186-61ac-46d7-9852-6ca2b6b4b717.chunk:
the reason that this works in general is that 
we have these sub problems. So, we have these sub   problems and we are combining these sub 
problems to solve our original problem. 
  So, for example, when I look at factorial of n, 
then I need to solve the

274736e8-6a90-4e2c-9813-679a0f36d8fa.title: Dynamic Programming
274736e8-6a90-4e2c-9813-679a0f36d8fa.chunk:
subproblem factorial of   n minus 1, but factorial of n minus 1, in turn, 
will ask me to solve the problem of factorial n   minus 2. So, all the smaller versions of 
factorial n minus 1, n minus 2 up to 0,   are all sub problems of the problem I am going

705c8b7c-43c0-4556-893b-7c320e9209df.title: Dynamic Programming
705c8b7c-43c0-4556-893b-7c320e9209df.chunk:
to 
solve now. And once I can solve them, I can kind   of bring them together and solve this problem. 
Similarly, if I want to sort a list,   I will have to do by insertion sort, 
then I will have to be able to sort   that prefix from 0 to n minus 1. So,

a000b8d6-2584-4fe5-b02b-ab553a84433c.title: Dynamic Programming
a000b8d6-2584-4fe5-b02b-ab553a84433c.chunk:
if I sought 
from 0 to n minus 1, then I can start from 0 to n,   but in general, I might end up having to sort 
different segments, so I should think about any   sequence Xi to Xj as a sub problem of this. 
So, now, let us look at this sub problem situati

ae66f5fb-3b98-43f3-b127-60f06180b8f9.title: Dynamic Programming
ae66f5fb-3b98-43f3-b127-60f06180b8f9.chunk:
on   in a different context. So, remember, 
this interval scheduling problems. So,   the interval scheduling problem is something we 
encountered when we looked at greedy algorithms.   So, we said that we had some resource. For 
example, we said there is a

6c3180c2-ce04-4278-9bcc-daf13e1164e9.title: Dynamic Programming
6c3180c2-ce04-4278-9bcc-daf13e1164e9.chunk:
video classroom,   which is going to be used by a number of faculty 
members, and each faculty member has a fixed slot,   so they have a time period when they would like to 
use the classroom. But since no two people can use   the classroom at the same ti

0ab88cf8-d073-495d-bab0-b15b51ffd174.title: Dynamic Programming
0ab88cf8-d073-495d-bab0-b15b51ffd174.chunk:
me, we have to choose 
a subset of slots to schedule during the week. 
  And in the interval scheduling problem 
our criterion was to keep the maximum   number of people happy. So, we wanted to 
satisfy as many requests as possible. So,   we wanted to choo

34617617-ef67-4328-8ff2-9fa613f156b4.title: Dynamic Programming
34617617-ef67-4328-8ff2-9fa613f156b4.chunk:
se a subset of bookings, so 
that, the number of teachers who got their booking   was maximized. We were not concerned about 
for example, maximizing the utilization of   the room in terms of the number of hours 
of recording or something like that. 
  So,

3b526189-9aab-474f-abc4-270c6ab10646.title: Dynamic Programming
3b526189-9aab-474f-abc4-270c6ab10646.chunk:
here we have subproblems. So, each subset 
of bookings is a sub problem. And we have this   greedy strategy, which says, pick based on some 
criterion, the first request to schedule. And   once I schedule that request, there are some other 
requests which

47285131-445f-44bd-b884-e6b576ea569b.title: Dynamic Programming
47285131-445f-44bd-b884-e6b576ea569b.chunk:
overlap with it, because they have   the starting time or ending time is such 
that I cannot schedule them both together.   So, I have to remove those. 
And once I remove that, I get   what remains, and that is a subset of the original 
problem which I ha

0af9f686-4bd5-4def-a7d6-ff0ee3bdccaf.title: Dynamic Programming
0af9f686-4bd5-4def-a7d6-ff0ee3bdccaf.chunk:
ve to solve. So, that is why   every subset in general is a sub problem. 
So, this is also there. So, this kind of   inductive structure, though we did not use 
an inductive solution in the greedy thing   there is an inductive thing going on. That 
is in o

da461ab8-95aa-458d-958b-0512c81f9dca.title: Dynamic Programming
da461ab8-95aa-458d-958b-0512c81f9dca.chunk:
rder to solve the whole problem, I   take something out and then I solve a 
smaller version of the same problem.
  So, each subset is a small, is a sub problem. 
Now, of course, since subsets are exponential,   if I have n bookings, there are 2 to the 
n s

53e52e54-28e6-48fc-8cf6-b0abc77466cf.title: Dynamic Programming
53e52e54-28e6-48fc-8cf6-b0abc77466cf.chunk:
ubsets that are in principle 2 to the n   different subproblems. So, ideally, I would need 
to look at all of these subsets. So, every subset   tells me something about how it can be solved 
and I would have to look at the best of these.   But the reason t

0811d08a-1a36-4abd-bd46-0a1bc0c7f18f.title: Dynamic Programming
0811d08a-1a36-4abd-bd46-0a1bc0c7f18f.chunk:
hat the greedy strategy 
is attractive is that it does not look   at all of them it only looks at a fraction of 
subproblems. But along with this, we have this   side effect that every choice that we make 
rules out a large number of subproblems,   so we n

cc3f709f-18f4-4669-a522-0c013eb5e506.title: Dynamic Programming
cc3f709f-18f4-4669-a522-0c013eb5e506.chunk:
eed to make sure that the optimal solution 
we are looking for has not been ruled out   by looking at by making a poor choice. 
So, whenever we make this kind of a greedy   strategy, then we need to prove optimality. 
Because we cannot be sure otherwise,

ecf8d533-c924-45b5-a8a2-f13039f1eaa3.title: Dynamic Programming
ecf8d533-c924-45b5-a8a2-f13039f1eaa3.chunk:
that the choices that we have thrown away, are not 
going to be bad. So, we saw that there were many   kinds of incorrect greedy strategy for which we 
could explicitly come up with counter examples.   Just because you cannot come up with a counter 
examp

b875458e-0732-4419-bd08-ce6d5a8bc324.title: Dynamic Programming
b875458e-0732-4419-bd08-ce6d5a8bc324.chunk:
le does not mean that the greedy strategy   is correct. So, you must necessarily prove that 
it is correct. And we gave some arguments for   it. We talked about exchange arguments or showing 
in this case that the interval scheduling using   the greedy str

698c87c4-d2ed-4de5-94df-10dcb0ee868f.title: Dynamic Programming
698c87c4-d2ed-4de5-94df-10dcb0ee868f.chunk:
ategy always stays ahead 
of the optimal schedule, and so on. 
  So, let us look at now a variant of this 
problem. So, remember, we said that in this   interval scheduling problem, we are only 
interested in maximizing the total utilization   in terms of

11580d91-8275-4c6c-ac8c-6a6ad44a477e.title: Dynamic Programming
11580d91-8275-4c6c-ac8c-6a6ad44a477e.chunk:
the faculty. We want to keep as many 
people happy as possible, but we are not looking   at any resource in terms of the room utilization.

is actually not

07cf7467-3118-46ba-a2e9-86fed1d5bbe3.title: Dynamic Programming
07cf7467-3118-46ba-a2e9-86fed1d5bbe3.chunk:
a captive resource inside IIT   Madras, but it is a commercial facility. So, in a 
commercial facility, so you charge rent for usage.   So, each person who makes a booking is willing 
to pay a certain amount of money. So, there is   a certain weight associ

d32ac55f-9b25-43fd-8f9b-8709eb798d5d.title: Dynamic Programming
d32ac55f-9b25-43fd-8f9b-8709eb798d5d.chunk:
ated with the booking.
It need not just be the length, it could also be   some people for have an urgent requirement, they 
are willing to pay more. So, for each request,   there is also a weight. You can think of 
it as how much money you are going to ear

3cbcf40b-93aa-4119-bb6a-b06a61014902.title: Dynamic Programming
3cbcf40b-93aa-4119-bb6a-b06a61014902.chunk:
n,   if you satisfy that request. But the constraint 
is still the same. That is these requests are   fixed in time, they must be from a starting 
time to an end time, they cannot shift.   And you cannot have two overlapping 
requests at the same time.

06117784-9fc2-40be-a566-c0223cca88a4.title: Dynamic Programming
06117784-9fc2-40be-a566-c0223cca88a4.chunk:
So now, our goal becomes different. We are no 
longer interested necessarily, in keeping the   maximum number of customers happy, rather, we 
are interested in maximizing our revenue. So,   as the owners of this facility, we would like 
to maximize the tot

1a82d112-96f8-471f-94e7-8904fdcafad8.title: Dynamic Programming
1a82d112-96f8-471f-94e7-8904fdcafad8.chunk:
al weight in this case,   the total income that we get as 
rent from renting out this facility.   So, if you remember the greedy strategy that 
we had for the earlier question, which is to   maximize the number of users who use it, we said 
that you just t

c2006ba5-9350-455f-a888-76661e530b39.title: Dynamic Programming
c2006ba5-9350-455f-a888-76661e530b39.chunk:
ake the earliest deadline.
  So, you look at the first job that is going to 
finish and schedule it first, knock out all the   jobs which overlap with it. Now among those that 
remain, you take the first job that is going to   schedule it and so on. So, we

39e4b6d5-20c6-4856-8de5-07a545c6dab6.title: Dynamic Programming
39e4b6d5-20c6-4856-8de5-07a545c6dab6.chunk:
had this earliest 
deadline or the earliest finish time as our greedy   strategy. But it is quite easy to come up with 
a weighted example where this does not work. 
  So here is a trivial case. So, I have 
three requests, two of them have weight 1,   and

85dc9236-ac96-4648-9764-ff6f0a0a39f5.title: Dynamic Programming
85dc9236-ac96-4648-9764-ff6f0a0a39f5.chunk:
one of them has weight 3. So, it is 
very clear that the best choice for me   is to use the job or to schedule the job, 
which is weight 3. Now, if I were just   trying to maximize a number of customers, as 
before, I would take this one and schedule it.

daa36737-89bb-4c2d-8448-faeebceeda37.title: Dynamic Programming
daa36737-89bb-4c2d-8448-faeebceeda37.chunk:
And then this would mean that this goes out. 
And then because the other one starts later I   would schedule that. So, I would get two happy 
customers, but my revenue would be only 2. 
  Whereas if I did not go by the earliest deadline, 
but somehow wer

72527f24-4ae9-4f37-a4f0-a66c5fa69225.title: Dynamic Programming
72527f24-4ae9-4f37-a4f0-a66c5fa69225.chunk:
e able to take into account the   weights that I had, then I would actually prefer 
to take just as one customer who is willing to   pay three units, and thereby get more than I 
would get by servicing the other two customers.   So, this earliest deadline

fff6f749-bd55-4646-bc64-30dcbc06cd2f.title: Dynamic Programming
fff6f749-bd55-4646-bc64-30dcbc06cd2f.chunk:
is no longer a valid 
greedy strategy if I add weights, and I now want   to maximize the weight of the schedule.

looking saying, okay, maybe I do not want   to do thi

s, maybe I want to find now. Remember

8c595593-c6a7-43ee-856a-9c38b374bbde.chunk:
or we can take revenue into   time or revenue divided by time.

to the or

b76317ca-bd6b-4d6b-b535-5ccd56a152c3.title: Dynamic Programming
b76317ca-bd6b-4d6b-b535-5ccd56a152c3.chunk:
iginal problem depends on subproblems.   So, can we take those subproblems and build up

to this weighted interval scheduling problem?
  So, here is a way

666593e3-ea07-4bb8-8458-89457d3cdb14.chunk:
to do that systematically. 
So, let us just arrange the jobs in some natural   order. So, we can say we can arrange them by their

first starting time B2 i

f601d5ff-42d3-46e8-9f6c-d1fee957ab71.chunk:
s a second starting time   and so on. Of course, they could have multiple

us for convenience assume that our n requests   have n different starting times and

c70d170b-daf0-4dbc-9473-82ac14070094.chunk:
B1 to Bn 
represents the order of the starting times in   increasing order.

the solution, but I know that either B1 is there   in the optimum solution or there is an optimum 
solution

1e046200-98fb-4469-8854-da302816665c.title: Dynamic Programming
1e046200-98fb-4469-8854-da302816665c.chunk:
without B1, there are only two choices.   Either I can find an optimum solution with

7a2316da-1846-432c-8b5a-c7e2f7489327.title: Dynamic Programming

solution or it is not.

sequence because the starting times is in an order   so maybe B2 over

laps maybe B3 overlaps maybe B4

jobs B2, B3 maybe which get ruled out,   so now I will

69dbad4e-6ade-412b-b357-e2ede0a59fcf.chunk:
have to solve the remaining

and I have a resulting problem,

3ac70170-fdaf-4b84-b32b-a1bdecfa4f97.chunk:
which has B2 up   to Bn. So, these are now my two subproblems.

not know whether I should have kept B1 or I should   have dropped B1 but let us assume inducti

314297f1-119d-4cb5-a7d2-7af8efb6d9a9.chunk:
vely 
I can solve these smaller subproblems. So,   we have solved the smaller subproblems, then I can 
just take the maximum of the two in the sense that   if I include B1 I get the revenue from B1 plus 
the whatever I have solved, if I exclude B1,   I get

199d1f98-8718-473b-9323-b68cbcc0f5fd.chunk:
the revenue for whatever else, but I do 
not get the revenue of B1, whichever of them   gives me more revenue more weight I use that.

Now, why is it guaranteed

470d2c7b-4ea2-4938-93ca-0bba1bfd41d8.title: Dynamic Programming
470d2c7b-4ea2-4938-93ca-0bba1bfd41d8.chunk:
to be correct?   Because it does not rule out any possibility

onsider it in the subproblems involving

tee because if I throw out B1,   B2 still is possible. So, then I would check

ot 
there. So, there is no problem. So,   I am not ruling out the fact that B1 was there.

So, when I get to B3, either it has been   allowed by my previous choices or it has been

er these   jobs are arranged in starting time order. So, B1

then 
this is gone and I am looking at these things.   So, these are the two sub problems in

So, now,
